content.description: In plants the enzyme <math alttext="E P S P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>EPSP</mi></math> synthase catalyzes a reaction between two different substrates, <math alttext="S 3 P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi><mn>3</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi></math> and <math alttext="P E P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>PEP</mi></math>, to form a product used in the synthesis of three amino acids. The structure of glyphosate, the active chemical in many herbicides, is very similar to that of <math alttext="P E P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>PEP</mi></math>.
content.question: Which of the following explains how glyphosate most likely functions as an herbicide?

choices.label: Glyphosate prevents synthesis of the three amino acids by competing with <math alttext="P E P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>PEP</mi></math> for binding to the active site of <math alttext="E P S P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>EPSP</mi></math> synthase.

Glyphosate prevents synthesis of the three amino acids by binding to an allosteric site of <math alttext="E P S P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>EPSP</mi></math> synthase, increasing the likelihood that <math alttext="P E P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>PEP</mi></math> will bind to the active site.

Glyphosate causes too much synthesis of the three amino acids by reducing the activation energy of the reaction catalyzed by <math alttext="E P S P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>EPSP</mi></math> synthase.

Glyphosate alters the structure of the three amino acids by binding to both <math alttext="S 3 P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi><mn>3</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi></math> and <math alttext="P E P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>PEP</mi></math> in the active site of <math alttext="E P S P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>EPSP</mi></math> synthase.

content.answer: Glyphosate prevents synthesis of the three amino acids by competing with <math alttext="P E P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>PEP</mi></math> for binding to the active site of <math alttext="E P S P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>EPSP</mi></math> synthase.
